reviewText:
This is my favourite FPS of all time next to Heretic - Shadow of The Serpent Riders, DooM 2 is a multi-layered FPS game which is the purest example of how the genre should be, fast paced, challenging and meticulously well designed. The levels in DooM 2 are absolute masterpieces, each their own puzzle and often require good navigational skills as some are extremely elaborate and focus on non-linearity and good resource management.

As like the original DooM, the visuals in this are a work of art, each and every texture feels in place, the concept couldn't get much better, the atmosphere is evil and consistent and the architecture is flawless. DooM 2's gameplay is incredibly fast-paced and requires you to maneuver skillfully through hordes of monsters and causing 'in-fighting' between monsters to conserve ammunition.

Each and every slight detail of design this game has was put into consideration; monster placement, switches, the way you progress, keys scattered around the map, secrets, traps, FPS has only come downhill from here, regardless of all the flashy cutscenes and graphics presented in todays games this offers a far deeper experience than pretty much every FPS to date.

DooM 2 is the definitive FPS experience showing how great gameplay and level design work hand in hand with each other and how important that combination is in creating a flawless masterpiece, this is one game I complete atleast 3 times a year from start to finish and have more fun in it with each playthrough, I recommend you play this on Ultra-Violence as that is the way its meant to be played and without saving throughout the levels as that takes away a lot of the challenege.

reviewText:
Doom 2 is the second game of the franchise coming out only a year after the original was released. It is set right after the events that took place in Episode 3 of the first game where you have managed to return to Earth only to discover that it has come under attack by the forces of hell. It doesn't take long to find out why humanity is on the verge of extinction as the amount of monsters you see on Earth is more than you even see exploring hell in the first game. To make matters worse they have sent brand new demons such as the Archvile, chain-gun wielding zombies and other demons far more powerful than those you spent the majority of the time fighting in Doom 1. This is definitely a sequel made for those with lots of experience playing the original and will hold no punches back. It is a far more difficult game than the original, as such I would suggest starting with that one if you are looking to get in to the series. If you simply want to play some of the insane number of mods available then this is the one to get since must mods are for Doom 2.

The only new gun in your arsenal will be a double barreled shotgun and packs a heck of a punch to anyone in its path but lacks the great range of the single barreled shotgun making both viable options instead of a straight upgrade. One of the first things you may notice is that there are no longer any Episodes to choose from. Instead you start from level 1 and make your way to the end of the game from there. It sucks not being able to start at the middle or the end of the game anymore though I did find this change to be for the better overall as you no longer end an episode and have to collect all your weapons over again when you start the next one. You may be thinking that has the potential to make the game too easy as you can now stock up on tons of ammo but that is not the case. Due to the powerful new enemies and the sheer amount of numbers they throw at you, ammo feels more valuable than ever. In the original game you would tend to stick to the shotgun the majority of the time to save ammo for Cyberdemons but in Doom 2 that will more likely than not get you killed as it is very difficult to handle the new monsters with a shotgun alone.

While the Cyberdemon is still the most powerful enemy you will face I somehow fear the Archvile just as much or even more. It is quite a nasty monster that will set you on fire if it can see you requiring you to hide behind any objects or walls to break its line of sight. All the while it resurrects previously defeated enemies making your situation far more dire every moment that it remains alive. Those are the kind of moments you will more likely than not swap out your trusty shotgun and use up much rarer ammo types in the hopes that you won't need it later. The level design in this is downright sadistic and will lock you into small rooms full of enemies, descend the floor beneath you to fall face to face with an enemy or place enemies in hard to reach vantage points as they suddenly pelt you from above. Levels are much larger this time around and there is a big focus on verticality. The verticality can be very annoying as you cannot look up to shoot at them unless you are playing Doom 2 via a source port that gives you mouse aiming. Even then it is quite a rush as you are surrounded on from all sides and are even being shot at from above lending the game the feel that you are really fighting for your survival.

In Doom 1 more often than not you felt like you were a badass but in Doom 2 you really get the feeling that you are just surviving as the slightest mistake can be the end of you. Many of the times you will not see the fight coming as the walls drop around you to reveal that you are indeed surrounded in a room that appeared safe. It is a lot more action oriented than the original that had the sounds and groans of the enemy far before you see it to give it a bit of a horror feel. In this it is a lot more in your face merely dropping enemies without much indication. Whichever you enjoy more is up to preference though in some occasions Doom 2 does end up feeling down right cheap. One other thing I am not too crazy about is the obscurely hidden keycards for a few levels. I usually ended up finding them while searching for secrets only to discover that is actually the right way to go. I can see many players being completely stuck in some levels and ending up searching for a walkthrough. Thankfully most of the levels do not have obscure level design and flow rather well with you knowing where to go at all times.

All of the items make a return like the hazmat suit, night vision and soul spheres with no new additions. Secrets are still plentiful and more important than ever as finding a crate of rare ammo can be the difference between life or death down the road. If you die you start at the beginning of the level with only a pistol like in the original Doom. Environments were very impressive for their time featuring giant cities with skyscrapers and tons of things on screen. I still find it rather cool even today as everything you see will eventually be explored and is not just set dressing. Being able to fight in a large nonlinear city, shooting rockets while running faster than Sonic the Hedgehog is a lost art in modern FPS games sadly. Music is strangely enough no longer guitar shredding Metal and is instead a more laid back Industrial Techno sounding type of genre. It is strange as Doom 2 is a lot more action packed than the original and yet is the one with music that doesn't get you pumped. It has some really good tracks nonetheless and is really just up to personal preference. Controls have been modernized and has movement set to “WASD” with the mouse controls allowing you to look left and right. Pushing the mouse forward causes your character to walk forward which is annoying and cannot be disabled without the use of a mod.

Your main mission is to help the remnants of humanity off the planet before being completely wiped out. Eventually you succeed in your mission and lay down your gun, sit back and wait for death while proud of the fact that you saved humanity. You get a call telling you that they found where the demons are pouring in from and you wearily stand back up to continue the fight. It sounds a lot better than it is to be honest. Story is minimal and you only get a bit of text from time to time. Like pretty much any other shooter at the time it is all about gameplay and it is still as fun now as it was back then. It is the same timeless gameplay from Doom 1 but with the addition of plenty of new powerful demons and much harder levels. If you liked Doom this is really more of the same only bigger, badder and more likely to make you John Romero's b****. At the low price it is now being sold at it is more than worth it to take a trip back to memory lane or to any fan of fast and frantic FPS action that's willing to look past the dated graphics. So rev up your chainguns and mow down demons until you are knee deep in the dead.

reviewText:
Doom was a series that blew me away when I was younger. I was born right before the advent of 3D gaming, so I grew up with the progression from 16-bit to 32-bit and then full on polygonal games. It felt like technology was moving so fast and that I was at the cusp of creativity.

Even though Super Mario 64 had changed how I viewed gaming, Doom came into my life and changed what I thought of my PC. I now wanted to master the keyboard and mouse so that I could become a Doom god. I eventually got my own PC and Doom became my best friend.

What I found was, I had a stronger fondness for Doom II. I couldn't explain it then, but I felt like the game was more intense. It seemed to move faster, had bigger levels and a greater variety of enemies. Even if it bared resemblance to the original Doom, it felt like a totally different game.

I can now explain why I felt such a way. ID Software were always looking to outdo themselves. All of the creators had become masters of their own game, so they looked on how to up the challenge. Throwing simply more enemies would be cheap, but it also could work with some slight modifications to the gunplay.

This brought about the Super Shotgun (or Double Barrell), which has such a significant impact on combat scenarios and level design. Since you basically have a gun that is close range with the damage of a rocket launcher (and no splash damage), you can destroy lesser foes in a single shot.

It turns some of the drawn out encounters from the first game into lightning fast executions. You can clear out rooms of weaklings in mere seconds, where the original Doom required you to carefully plan out whom to attack first. That does still factor into Doom II, what with the enemies retaining their simplistic designs and the new enemies being super deadly; the change is now that there are dramatically more enemies.

The levels are much larger than anything from the first game, so you will encounter hundreds of foes in single levels. Your  arsenal will grow over the course of the game and you'll eventually find yourself with a large amount of ammunition. If nothing was done to even the odds, you'd be overpowered within 5 levels.

While not every map is a masterpiece, the majority of this game has more in-depth designs. Vertical spacing is delved into; differing level heights play a bigger role; there are even some gimmick levels that throw large bosses at you with a small puzzle to kill them. It's definitely not just bigger = better.

The game also does away with Episode selection and has you play all 30 levels back to back. If you get good at the game, you end up never losing your inventory. Most of the levels have ammo backpacks, so even if you do die, you're never left underpowered. You may run out of ammo, though.

The newer enemies help flesh out the roster a bit. The original game nearly blows it's entire line-up in the first Episode, saving the really big bosses for the later levels. Doom II introduces one weaker version of a previous enemy (the Hell Knight) and some real pain in the ♥♥♥, priority targets.

The Mancubus is basically a walking tank with double rocket launchers; the Pain Elemental acts as a mobile spawning point; the Revenant is hyper fast and strong (though with low health); finally, the Chaingun Guy has impeccable accuracy and speed with his chaingun. It introduces a more steady difficulty curve that doesn't need to reset at the start of every 8 or so levels (like how the original Doom handled it).

The Steam version of Doom II is also limited to being a DOSBox emulation (much like it's predecessor), so that does suck. With the aid of a source port, you can also get some co-op going. You can even clean up the visuals a bit and add some more modernized controls.

Overall, Doom II may not be as brilliantly made as the first game. I still enjoy the combat and larger levels more, but there is a sense that ID Software got a bit too ambitious. Regardless of that, there is no reason to pass up on playing this.

9/10

reviewText:
DOOM II is a worthy sequel to a classic FPS, which I've already written about if you somehow didn't know about it. This gives you 32 generally great new levels, a new weapon (the Super Shotgun - a double-barreled shotgun), and adds a number of new monsters that serve to elevate the gameplay even further.

And...that's it. It's honestly more of an expansion than a sequel. But trust me when I say that the game is all the more better for it, because pretty much every addition is an improvement. Doom fans view this as the pinnacle of classic Doom, and custom level designers have generally used it in lieu of the first game since it came out. Not that the first game is bad; with the lack of Doom II's new features it becomes an experience all its own. But if you get the first one, you'd do extremely well to grab its sequel as well.

Just don't play it with the included DOSBox emulator. What you're paying for is DOOM2.WAD - the game file itself. If you want a high quality experience, download Chocolate Doom if you want the closest thing to pure Doom, ZDoom if you want to easily play custom levels and mods, or Skulltag if you want to try multiplayer. Given how many of the aforementioned mods and custom levels there are, how many are still being made to this day, and how many good ones there are of varying types and stripes, you'd better believe it when I say it's worth it.

reviewText:
Fight your way threw waves of monsters invading earth in this PC cult classic. Doom II has set the way for PC gaming since the 90's and it's still one of the most if not THE most cult classic PC game ever made.

Game play: 9 out of 10

Being a game from the 90's doesn't stop this game from having some of the best game play for it's time. It may not be Call of Duty, or Half-life but it has really solid game. Doom II is the “Guns! Guns! Even more guns!” kinda of game play. Doom II is a simple a first person shooter, you move, you shoot, you get keys, to unlocked doors and find hidden stuff. Nothing over the top. However back in the 90's it didn't matter. It how many guns can I use to take out these monsters.

While Doom has it fair share of weapons, It has a great design of monsters monsters and more monsters! Everything from your basic zombie soldier, to huge ♥♥♥ cyber demons ready to rip you apart at a moments notice. Each monster has there own style of game play. Some has simple things like a shot gun, or a melee attack, Some have more magical powers like fireballs or setting you on fire, while some are Cybernetic enhanced demons using rocket launchers or having a spider body with a chain gun on it. Whatever the case maybe this game doesn't sell you short on the fun factor.

Doom also uses the color key/door system. Meaning you have to search around from room to room finding these keys to advance in each level. In Doom II you do not have to really Aim at the targets it pretty much aims for you by using an auto aim system since you can't really look up and down and such. Pretty much means you can be standing on top of something and shoot something below you and not even be aiming or looking at it. There are ways to change this of course but please read blow for more info on that.

The maps are very well design, with each one having a different theme to them. However unlike games now of days one level leads into the next which leads into the next one Doom doesn't really have a set “level” design on how you go from one map to the next map. It's pretty much like an episodic tv show where you have the “flavor” or “theme” of the day. Here it's more so the “Flavor” or “theme” of the map.

There are a decent amount of power ups, You have Berserk mode, Radioactive suit, full map, and more. Each adds a little bit more to the game play element which adds even more fun to the game as it is.

Story: 5 out of 10.

Doom it's self has a good story... if you read the novels and such however the game it's self gives you a more simple smaller version of the story. There isn't much there to really work with. It's mainly about demons and monster that have came from hell that are invading earth and it's your job to stop it. Short and simple. This game isn't about the over all story as it is. It's mainly about kill everything that gets in your way.

Graphics: 9 out of 10.

Of course the graphics are pretty bad compare to games now but for it's time they where amazing. It's a 3D game with 2d rending sprites. Every NPC and items around the maps them self’s are 2D sprites that “follows” you. Pretty much whenever you step left or right it will turn and keep looking at you. While there are times when the graphics of NPC's and items can look flat by the way you are looking at them, but doesn't effect the game play.

The over all graphics are set to be more Gorey/ Horror themed with a dark gloomy setting. While a lot of maps focus on a certain theme for each one, you can get the over all feel they where going for.

Music: 10 out of 10.

This music in this game is amazing. For being midi files it is top notice. The music is midi version of song like Master of Puppets by metallica to other big named bands. The sound track will have to coming back for more. Doom has one of the best sound tracks in history for video games.

DOOM II's gameplay is much the same as the first game with very few changes.

The super shotgun is a fantastic(ally overpowered) addition.  It's satisfying to use, does as much damage as a rocket, and uses pretty common ammo... except most of the levels (Petersen's, so you know who to go strangle blame) are huge, have long sight lines, and are swarmed with monsters that do not drop ammuntion.  The variable lighting from the first game is less present this time around, too.

On the note of the level design, I'd like to cite Map 10 in particular:  the only seemingly reasonable way to do this map is to kite every enemy on the map to the entry hallway and gun them down as they catch themselves in chokepoints...  which is what I did, after several failed attempts at running and gunning my way in (since all of the rooms had enough hitscan enemies to make that impossible).

The new enemies feel gimmicky and most have very simple strategies associated with them:
The giant skeletons will try to punch you if you get near them, but cannot punch and move at the same time
The flying meatballs will not spawn skulls (or attack in any way) if you are touching them
The archvile's flames will go out if you hide behind a wall (of any width!)

Many of them just feel annoying and I'd compare the meatballs to Satan if they weren't already demons.  Fighting them is like stepping on Legos.

Granted, I haven't finished the game yet, but I don't think there's much left that could change my mind at this point.  The level design of the first game was probably the best thing about it (although it had a lot going for it), and the second game's level design really does not play towards the game's strengths.  Is it fun?  On the better designed levels, yes.  Is it as good as the first game?  No.  Play DTWID if you want more of the first game.

Rip and tear me a new one if you like.  /opinions

Doom 2 is a classic that maintains its fun to this day. At first glance, it looks very similar to Doom 1, using many of the same graphics, the same gunplay, and the same arsenal (plus the new double barrelled shotgun). Where this game differs from its predecessor is in the level design and overall flow of the combat. Whereas Doom 1 was very mazelike and encounters were more personal with a handful of enemies, this game frequently drops you in huge, open areas and sometimes throws dozens of enemies at you at once. The double barrelled shotgun changes the fight dynamics a great deal. Where the Pink demons were a challenge in the first game, they can be dispatched with one blast, and other enemies that were difficult to deal with are similarly cut down to size. To compensate for this, Doom 2 introduces a handful of new, more offensively focused enemies, such as the mancubus and revenant, which shoot rockets at you, and the archvile that catches you on fire and resurrects the dead. The effect that all of this has is that encounters in Doom 2 are usually more intense and challenging. As is the case in every classic Id software game, the level design is brilliant and encourages a kind of exploration you just don't get in today's FPS games. The levels are large and sprawling, but the clever design gives each level a sense of direction and flow, so you generally know where to go next. I can think of exactly two spots where the way to continue was overly obtuse (for those interested:  there was a keycard hidden in a very obscure place in the level Refueling Base" and having to shoot part of the wall to open a door in a level called "The Spirit World" ). DOOM II's gameplay is much the same as the first game with very few changes.

The super shotgun is a fantastic(ally overpowered) addition.  It's satisfying to use, does as much damage as a rocket, and uses pretty common ammo... except most of the levels (Petersen's, so you know who to go strangle blame) are huge, have long sight lines, and are swarmed with monsters that do not drop ammuntion.  The variable lighting from the first game is less present this time around, too.

On the note of the level design, I'd like to cite Map 10 in particular:  the only seemingly reasonable way to do this map is to kite every enemy on the map to the entry hallway and gun them down as they catch themselves in chokepoints...  which is what I did, after several failed attempts at running and gunning my way in (since all of the rooms had enough hitscan enemies to make that impossible).

The new enemies feel gimmicky and most have very simple strategies associated with them:
The giant skeletons will try to punch you if you get near them, but cannot punch and move at the same time
The flying meatballs will not spawn skulls (or attack in any way) if you are touching them
The archvile's flames will go out if you hide behind a wall (of any width!)

Many of them just feel annoying and I'd compare the meatballs to Satan if they weren't already demons.  Fighting them is like stepping on Legos.

Granted, I haven't finished the game yet, but I don't think there's much left that could change my mind at this point.  The level design of the first game was probably the best thing about it (although it had a lot going for it), and the second game's level design really does not play towards the game's strengths.  Is it fun?  On the better designed levels, yes.  Is it as good as the first game?  No.  Play DTWID if you want more of the first game.

Rip and tear me a new one if you like.  /opinions

reviewText:
Well, the game itself sucks. Obviously, it was mind-blowingly cool for when it came out, but for todays standards...

I mean, the graphics are crap, the gunplay is unsatisfying, you have access to all your guns but you only use the best one you have at the time. The maps are maze-like, you spend half of your play time wandering around looking for key-cards.

But, for the mods?

The mods make this game way better. You have a little tiny bit of installer work to do, but once you do, it's totally worth the price.There's mods that simply improve the games mechanics and graphics, to mods that completely overhaul and change the game. They stretch far and wide, from anime-style demon slaying action, magic spells, punching people in the face, MAP PACKS, and of course straight up rip and tear brutality. The community has kept this game alive. On some particular mods, like Zandronum, the game even has an active multiplayer community. Wow.

You need to buy this game for the mods, by the way. No pirating for you!

Yeah, as long as your willing to do a little digital labour, this game is totally worth it. This goes for all of the other Doom games too, most if not, all mods work for all of them.

DOOM II, the grandfather of the modern FPS, is one of the finest games ever made... for its time, at least. Every last monster was built out of clay and are turned into sprites, so the game looks a bit like a demented Robot Chicken skit. However, in the days of Windows 8 and whatnot, the game no longer works without a bit of setup. Luckily, there are guides on how to set up and configure everything so you can run the game on your new machines. The controls can feel a bit slippery, but overall the ultimate FPS still holds up today in all of its glory. If you are willing to drop a few dollars to experience history, then DOOM, or more specifically DOOM II, will be your gateway into the underworld.

Okay, so if you liked the first Doom, Doom II is basically everything Doom was, except bigger and better. The first thing I noticed about this game was that there were more textures, and a LOT more enemies. Levels have more depth to them, are much larger, and more often than not have well over 100 sprites onscreen. Sitting back in '94,this would've been pushing the limits of PCs, no longer being confined to small corridors and just a handful of enemies at a time. The only downside was the story, but the action-oriented gameplay perfected by ID software makes up for it, who seem to have had an everlasting obsession with the idea of being sent to Hell.

Doom II also added 2 player co-operative (not present in the Steam version) building upon the 4 player deathmatch mode, supporting up to 16 players on one server! Basically, this game gives you a whole lot more of what the first Doom gave you.

I'd give it a 9.5/10 considering the time it was made, it only loses points for story.

reviewText: Bigger, badder, more explosive than its predecessor. It's a good game, but it lacks some of the artful cohesion that made the original DOOM so great. The original game did a lot better at telling a story through its level design and gameplay. The levels in DOOM II, by contrast, feel much more abstract, and feel more engineered to antagonize the player than the original DOOM. That said, the mechanics are (for better or worse) exactly the same as the first game, adding one new gun and a host of new upper-mid-tier enemies. There's plenty of great levels here, all things considered, it's just a shame that the sequel to DOOM feels more like a fan-made expansion pack than a full-fledged sequel.\n\nPresentation-wise, the Steam version of the game runs through DosBOX, which is serviceable, but feels a little low-effort. Fortunately, the game files are all there, so it's not difficult at all to find a source port to suit one's tastes.

After getting it running, the frame rate was really choppy and only playable in a reduced size window.  I remember seeing it on a 486 and being wow-ed seeing it run at full screen.  I also remember the first time seeing a chainsaw used as a weapon, which was really unheard of back in those days (Mortal Kombat had not hit the arcades yet).\nSo how does DOOM II hold up after all these years?  I will admit, when I started it up, it looked down right ugly running at full screen.  No joystick compatibility was a bummer as well.  I seem to remember my Gravis gamepad working on the original DOOM II back in the day, which I bought a Creative Labs Sound Blaster card specifically for the joystick port.  The level design seems to hold up well, and I still remembered many of the secret rooms.  I actually jumped a little when an imp popped out behind a hidden door, which I had forgotten about after all of these years.\nTo be honest, I had more fun playing this classic than playing any of the current FPS games.  You press enter, pick a difficulty, and you are playing.  In games these days, you have to sit through minutes and minutes of boring dialogue and cutscenes before you can do anything. This is probably the first time I've ever seen a game sequel be just as competent as it's predecessor, without really raising or lowering the bar.

I like DOOM. I like it a lot. And with all the hype behind the new DOOM 2016, I just couldn't help myself but throw some more hours into beating its sequel: Hell on Earth.

Because DOOM 2016 would beat my poor little laptop to death.

DOOM II takes place right after DOOM I, where Doomguy gets back from Mars to see earth covered with demons, and decides to take care of the problem the same way he did previously- by killing every demon that stands in his way. Like Carmack said, the story in games aren't important. While I may disagree with that statement, I do agree that an action-based should focus more on keeping you in the action as much as it can. And DOOM I and II both succeed in that, in my opinion.

With making a sequel, there's often the question of what will be added on to the new entry. With DOOM II there is a wide variety of new levels that are much more intuitively-designed than the first game, along with a new onslaught of enemies to face, including one of my least favorite enemies ever: The Pain Elementals. F*** those guys. Seriously. F*** those guys.

Surprisingly, as far as new content goes, besides the new enemies and levels, all you're given for new weapons is the super shotgun, which quickly became my favorite weapon. It uses two shotgun shells per round, and does extra damage as opposed to the standard shotgun. The game is challenging with all this new stuff, and I found myself in the DOOM-daze, where all I can think about over the week is playing more DOOM and getting more and more sucked in with every playthrough.

This is a very addicting game, but one flaw I saw throughout it (besides the lack of story) would be how the game really feels like an expansion to the original DOOM. It may have the run-time of a full game, but the textures, mixtures of old enemies with the new ones, and same arsenal as the first game, makes the game feel like more of DOOM I. I personally believe a game should accel from the foundation of the first game, but whether you disagree or agree with me is entirely your choice.

I won't deny that I love this game still. Just as much as the first DOOM. It's fast-paced, looks great, sounds great, and is addicting from start to finish. But since a lot of it does feel like the first game just bleeding into a sequel, I'm giving it the exact same score I'd give DOOM. A 7/10.
